intro: Cacalia triphylla, commonly known as the three-leaved bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and thrives in partial shade. Its leaves are trifoliate, meaning they are divided into three leaflets, giving it its common name. Cacalia triphylla produces blue to purple flowers that bloom in the spring and attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
